reviewText: Lars Lindstrom is a 27-year-old bachelor who has become such a loner of late that even his brother and sister-in-law have trouble getting him to come over for dinner.  Everyone seems to like Lars but no one seems to know how to break through the emotional barrier he's built up between himself and the world around him.  Karin, his sister-in-law, has become especially concerned about the eccentric behavior he has been exhibiting lately, but even she is unprepared for how far Lars is about to go in making people question his very sanity.The jolt comes when Lars, in his loneliness, decides to order up a life-sized, anatomically correct "love doll" off the internet (not for purposes of sex, mind you, but for love and companionship).  Soon he is bringing her to family get-togethers and social functions, thoroughly convinced that "Bianca" is a real live human being - and fully expecting everyone else around him to think so as well.  The local doctor suspects that Lars may be suffering from some sort of a "delusion" and that the best treatment would be for everyone, at least for the moment, to just play along with the fantasy.  Thus, all the astonishingly cooperative residents of this small Canadian town become participants in what must surely be the most impressive case of "mass therapy" in the history of psychoanalysis."Lars and the Real Girl" is clearly intended to be a fey fantasy on the order of, say, "Don Juan de Marco" or "The Madness of King George," so questioning the credibility and logic of much of  what takes place would be counterproductive to the filmmakers' point and purpose.  Indeed, the viewer should know going into the movie that he will be called upon to leave at least a portion of his skepticism at the door if he is to have any hope at all of entering fully into the spirit of the enterprise.  For the most part, I was able to set aside most of my more rational objections and to see the movie for the wry, offbeat parable that it is clearly intended to be.  Like Don Quixote - Lars' Dulcinea may not be a flesh-and-blood person, but she`s every bit as illusory as the Don`s ideal woman - this young man is obviously struggling with some pretty serious developmental issues and using fantasy as a means of shielding himself from the harsh realities of everyday life.  Writer Nancy Oliver and director Craig Gillespie don't provide clear-cut explanations for Lars' alienation, though there are hints that feelings of abandonment as a child may have played a significant role in it.  The point is that Lars, like so many others who are unprepared for the responsibilities of life and love, clearly needs time to work through his struggles, and he seems to be using his relationship with Bianca as the means of doing just that.This sort of delicately wry fable stands or falls on the conviction that each individual on both sides of the camera brings to the project.  One false move or jarring note on the part of any of the actors and the entire enterprise could come crashing down around them.  Luckily, the moviemakers are blessed with having the wonderful Ryan Gosling in the lead role.  This amazingly versatile and talented actor brings such a self-effacing sweetness and vulnerability to the role of Lars that even the most cynical among us can see why the townsfolk work so hard at buttressing his fantasy.  He gets beautiful support from Emily Mortimer, Paul Schneider, Kelli Garner and Patricia Clarkson as the individuals whose unqualified backing helps him through his crisis.  Moreover, the subdued tone, hypnotic pacing, and stark wintry backgrounds help to keep the fantasy grounded enough in reality to make us actually believe it could be happening.Given the material, "Lars and the Real Girl" could easily have become one long extended dirty joke or a one-note comical gimmick that failed to grow and develop much past the novelty stage.  Instead, we are given a fully formed, though-provoking little comedy that has a great deal to say about becoming an active part in the world around us.
summary: fantasy as an element in healing

reviewText: To tell you the truth, at first I wasn't interested in seeing this movie.  It sounded kinda hokey....about a guy who was dating a doll--and I mean a REAL doll. This type of behavior should not be a surprise in modern times.  I see it everywhere.  Isn't it always easier to express and show our love for someone who doesn't talk back and cause us grief?  Isn' that why a lot of lonely people have pets?  As far as I'm concerned, Lars was behaving no differently than a dog owner.  He had a lot of loving and caring to give to a woman but was afraid and probably didn't know how to do it.  So he chose a doll called Bianca.  Unfortunately, it's a sad reflection of our society on how disconnected we have become in this industrialized and computerized society.  But enough with all this philosophical mumbo jumbo.  LARS AND THE REAL GIRL was also REALLY funny.  The performances were terrific--especially Ryan Gosling, Emily Mortimer and Paul Schneider.  Not to sound condescending but LARS AND THE REAL GIRL seemed more like a foreign film--albeit a French film--than an American movie. reviewText: I saw this movie playing at a theater in the town I live in. The theater is generally selective about which movies it shows and I usually like the movies I see there. I actually was able to get the dvd from the library. I am so glad I didn't see the movie in the theater!As other reviewers who agree that this is simply an abominable movie have stated, it is amazing how many people thought that this movie was so great. I really resonated with a reviewer at amazon who said that while reading the large number of very glowing reviews, he thought that he must be from another planet."Lars and the Real Girl" is insipid, trite nonsense. It takes a totally unrealistic view of the subject of delusional people, and then gets much worse because the other premises born out in the very poor script are at least as bad as the original premise. I have a lot of experience with mental illness in my family, and I have visited many mental institutions. To believe that a person who is as delusional as Lars would behave as well as he did, to believe that he could hold a job and basically function, is just ridiculous. Delusional people often create painful, even unbearable incidents with people in their family and in other circumstances, and they often have absolutely no conscience about what they are doing, which is one of the reasons why there are often years and years of such incidents, and also one of the reasons why they are institutionalized. There is no way a person who is so delusional could as if "compartmentalize" the illness, channel it, solely into an imaginary mannequin girlfriend.The GP doctor, who is "coincidentally" also a psychologist, is also pure bunk, totally unrealistic, and the dialogues between her and Lars are silly and often pathetic. For example, to imply that people are crazy because of the crazy world we live in, and to imply that the basic problems that just about everyone has, are somehow the same as someone who is very sick, is way off the mark, in my opinion and experience. You can be sure that a person who has dealt with mentally ill people might question his/her own sanity, but that in no way means that questioning one's sanity is the same as being very delusional. I must confess, I fast forwarded after the first few of these weird conversations, so please excuse if I don't have a more informed critique of what was actually said, but this is what I got from the doctor-patient scenes that I did watch.Need I go on? The people in the small town going along with the delusional charade of the mannequin girlfriend is not believable and badly done as well, and I know that it doesn't work that way at all in "real" life. The funeral after the girlfriend "dies" is a joke. But her "death" does clear the way for Lars's to go out with the always available pretty girl, whose character is another gross oversimplification of "real" life, and is yet another example of how absurd this movie is.

reviewText: This film surprised me.  I knew the premise - a guy falls in love with a sex doll.  I must admit I wasn't expecting much, and certainly not a gem of a movie.  But out of that strange and simple premise grows a film that is sweet, touching, romantic, and will stay with you for a long time.  If you are willing to suspend your initial disbelief, you will find this movie oddly moving.  It reminded me a bit of the 1950 classic "Harvey," with a sex doll in place of Jimmy Stewart's giant, invisible rabbit friend.  As in that movie, when people put aside their initial judgments and confusion, they begin to discover something about themselves.  Both Harvey and Bianca function as mirrors for the people who "see" them. This movie offers reflections on the nature and necessity of community and the meaning that can be found if we are willing to act out of true compassion and not just out of cultural or normative habits.  This film also offers a positive portrayal of organized religion and people trying to live out their faith in real ways, something you don't find in a lot of Hollywood films.  There is wisdom in this film, but it is presented in such an understated and subtle way (again not something I was expected based on the premise) that it really builds AFTER you have seen the film and begin to think more about it.  I highly recommend this film - it is not what you think!  It is much better, and richer, and a real treasure.

reviewText: I lost count of the number of reviewers who say this movie is quirky, weird, funny, likeable and heartwarming. It's all of those things, but I want to try to dig beneath the surface a little, and there will be spoilers.First, this movie is the best advertisement that the RealDolls company could have dreamed of, though Lars (Ryan Gosling) is certainly not a typical customer for such an expensive and lifelike doll. Lars is delusional and imagines that Bianca (the doll) is his real-life girlfriend. Lars is an extremely sensitive soul and seems to suffer from extreme social anxieties, but apparently he has no history of delusions. The story takes place in a small, rather remote town, and the doctor, a widow named Dagmar who also happens to be a psychologist, announces that Lars' delusion is not the result of mental illness, but merely a manifestation of unresolved issues. Her prescription is to ask the entire town to play along with Lars, treating Bianca as a real person.All of this is implausible enough and I don't have to explain why. It's enjoyable to go along for the ride. But from this premise, a moral to the story emerges, and this is it: Love and acceptance can comfort and heal. There is no hate in this town. Even the people who are pious do not judge or hate. Even the redneck boys do not mock or bully. From the old ones down to the youngest children, there is only love and acceptance. Sometimes there is a little teasing and hurt feelings, but the worst of it is milder than anything you'd find in a modern Kindergarten class. Seeing such a bucolic town, I couldn't help but wonder what a man like Harold Hill (The Music Man) would do if he came upon it.Okay, so if the moral is "All You Need Is Love," what then? Watching this movie, you will be steeped in love. I'm no psychologist, but in some ways I think Lars behaves a bit like someone with autism, and the doll serves as a safe proxy for real people. With Bianca as an emotional crutch, Lars slowly learns how to interact with people, starting with his own family. The movie indulges in a lot of conveniences; for example, even with all his extreme anxieties and delusions, Lars is very easy for normal people to deal with. He's perfectly capable of understanding what people say to him, of taking care of himself, and of working at some kind of full-time computer-type job. I doubt that this is the case for most people who suffer from extreme anxieties and delusions. Making Lars sweet, likeable and independent makes it very easy to like him and enjoy the movie, but it strikes me as a bit too convenient and pleasant. It's simply not this easy and amusing to deal with people who suffer from serious mental illness, so, at best, the moral of "All You Need Is Love" is superficial and cloying.The story suffers from a couple of its own delusions. First, there is a beautiful gal, Margo (Kelli Garner) who is hopelessly in love with Lars, even as he loves Bianca. We never get to know anything substantial about Margo, though there are hints that she suffers from some emotional issues as well. In fact, there are more than a few characters who seem to suffer from emotional issues, which is strange considering that hate and cruelty are absent from this town. The makeup artists try hard to make Margo look plain, but they're not fooling anyone. As far as I could tell, Margo feels attracted to Lars because she is an extremely sensitive soul, too. But unlike Lars, she is "strong" enough to admit that she feels lonely and to try and do something about it, whereas Lars was in full retreat, at least until he met Bianca. Margo is trying to get from Lars what Lars is getting from Bianca, and by movie's end there's every indication that Lars and Margo will end up together. The other delusion is the notion that the "normal" people of this town are touched in some profound way by Bianca. They proceed to engage with Bianca well beyond what is required for indulging Lars' delusions, including Bianca "reading" stories to kids in the public schools (without Lars being present). Absolutely no explanation is offered for this. I have to wonder if there is perhaps a significant amount of lead or mercury in the drinking water of this town.I wouldn't suggest that anyone should skip this movie, especially if you enjoy quirky movies. There! I said I wouldn't say it and I said it - it's quirky! I suffer from delusions, too. Don't we all?

reviewText: Just so we are all on the same page, let me understand this correctly. A delusional office worker decides one day that it is time for him to find love and decides that rather than court a pleasant lass he instead chooses to order an "adult" doll as his lover and companion. Then the townspeople learn to embrace said doll as an almost real entity based solely on the delusional conversations and fictitious life that said office worker has crafted for his new lady. And you want me to believe that this is the foundation of a good movie?Certainly there has been a lot of hype about the movie Lars and The Real Girl; however, I for one cannot see what all the fuss is about. The movie is a rather boring take upon the traditional love story gone awry thanks in part to the delusional fantasy of a character that too often reminds me of Napoleon Dyanmite's half-brother.Lars Lindstrom (Ryan Gossling) is your everyday office cubicle nerd that has an awkward life complete with a lack of positive social interactions and making a home for himself in the family garage. While his brother Gus (Paul Scheider) and his wife Karin (Emily Mortimer) live inside the house that Gus and Lars grew up in, Lars' reserved and simplistic life in the garage detaches himself from even having a simple dinner with his brother and sister-in-law.Thanks in part to nothing more than an offbeat discussion amongst co-workers about the possibility of purchasing an "adult" doll, Lars decides that he would purchase such a life sized doll. However, as his co-workers perhaps were thinking more about the sexual benefits of such a doll, Lars instead seems interested in courting the doll and bringing her into his life as his significant other.While certainly his new found girlfriend, who might be more accurately defined as a dollfriend, really cannot speak or show much affection back to Lars it is his delusional mind that creates an entire life for Bianca. Lars crafts a life and story for Bianca complete with the rationale for why she is restricted to a wheelchair to her family background to her hobbies and interests.But what is stranger is that the entire community then embraces Bianca as one of their own. Though it likely was initially done simply to appease Lars and exhibit a certain sense of sympathy for his newfound delusional mind, the community then embraces Bianca more and more. She goes from being a delusional aspect of Lars' mind to being a volunteer at the hospital and a churchgoing member of society.It is hard to understand where Lars' delusions come from in relation to Bianca as before her arrival on the delivery truck he certainly seemed a tad off but certainly not delusional. One might speculate that his love for Bianca was simply a way to gain the attention of a real life co-worker named Margo (Kelli Garner) that Lars seems to have an awkward liking for, as well.Directed by Craig Gillespie and written by Nancy Oliver, Lars and the Real Girl is a movie that just doesn't seem to make it. Though credit could be given for the fact that this is indeed a very different plot and storyline to a film, it is also a bit too far out there at the same time. Although Lars and the Real Girl received a 2008 Oscar Nomination for Best Writing, I believe that this film lacked any significant writing that would warrant such a nomination. Throughout the entire film one cannot help but think to themselves, "Am I missing something?"The film is rather slow throughout and is less than imaginative in terms of substance. There are plenty of times throughout the movie that the story seems stale and the acting seems to be an act of just going through the motions rather than being a good example of embodying the character involved.Though in the film we gain a glimpse into the mind of a delusional character named Lars, the only think we are left with post-movie is the question as to whether or not fans of this film are themselves also in a delusional state of mind.

reviewText: What an amazing, delicate little movie.  There are so many missteps Lars and the Real Girl could have taken.  It could have quickly degenerated into a tacky sex comedy.  Or an immature cheap-laugh fest.  Opportunities abound for bad taste.  Where screenwriter Nancy Oliver demonstrates her great sensitivity and sense of nuance is in how she handles the story's various twists and turns without every falling into obvious traps.  In fact, in outline form her screenplay must have looked like the very way *not* to do it: there's little overt conflict, few missteps by major characters.  Without friction, I can imagine a scripting critic saying, "There's no conflict for XX pages.  You have to have a big fight.  If everybody goes along with it nothing happens."  Ah, yes, that's the secret.  This movie, seemingly about as tasteless a subject as one can imagine, is as gentle and sweet as an embrace.The whole thing is delightfully low-key.  That's what makes it so believable (the New York Times' review not withstanding).  Ryan Gosling plays Lars with just the right combination of sweetness and genuine mental feebleness that we neither pity him nor dislike him--we just see him as human.  Emily Mortimer is the all-American midwest girl who in real life just happens to come from "across the pond."  Her husband, played by Paul Schneider, is Lars' one foil, the one person who doesn't fall in line right away.  But even he comes to understand that sometimes you have to take a leap of faith to understand someone else's personal demons.And then there's Kelli Garner.  Despite the waif-like character she plays in this movie, all buck-toothed and wide-eyed, she's actually quite the babe.  If she keeps turning out good work like this, she could have quite a career ahead of her.  The scene where she and Lars go bowling is amazing in everything that is *not* said.  Body language--his and hers--tells the whole story.  The movie is quietly and confidently directed by first-time filmmaker Craig Gillespie.  He never feels compelled to push things along or kick up the drama via any artificial methods.  He and the film know where they're going from the first scene, and they get their at the perfect clip and the perfect pitch.  There's not a single misstep in this movie, and that's rare.Lars was up against Juno last year for best original screenplay, and Juno--more popular and heavily promoted--won.  While I enjoyed that movie immensely, Lars was harder to write, harder to direct.  Emotions weren't telegraphed.  Scenes did not progress along foreseeable paths, as they do in Juno.  Lars has many shadowy corners around which the plot twists in subtle directions.  It is so low-key that there is the danger constantly of drifting, meandering, yet this never happens.  Juno, fine as it was, didn't have this intricacy, and despite the subject matter was actually structured along fairly conventional lines.  But, ah, when did the Academy ever get it right?It's sad that rich, off-beat and "inner-driven" films like this are always super-low budget, with actors working for scale, and dark horses, even at the Oscars, which are supposed to recognize and stimulate the production of these kinds of pictures.  I'd recommend this picture, even if you think (especially if you think) the subject matter is off-putting.  It is precisely this sort of viewer who will be most surprised.  I would feel confident showing this movie in a church basement.  It's a sweet little film about acceptance, maturity, and love.
summary: A miracle of a screenplay in one of the most overlooked films of the year

reviewText: Sweet-natured and painfully shy Lars finally finds a girlfriend on the internet. Her name is Bianca, a life-sized love doll who has arrived in a packing crate. Lars treats her as a real person, though. First he introduces Bianca to his brother Gus and sister-in-law Karin at dinner before taking her to the church of the community in a wheelchair. Naturally Gus and Karin don't know what to do, but a local doctor advises them (and the entire townspeople) to go along with Lars's "delusion." The result is a charming, bittersweet tale of human nature.The unique film could not be a success without the convincing backstory of Lars himself. Nancy Oliver's screenplay gives us several hints as to the reasons for his shyness without interrupting the flow of the narrative. Lars lives in a garage and he doesn't want to touch people. We slowly come to understand him through Ryan Gosling's amazing performance as Lars, who makes his character endearing. No wonder the people of the community want him to be happy. By the end of the film's story, you will feel the same way too.The entire cast is great especially Paul Schneider as Gus, Emily Mortimer as Karin and most notably Patricia Clarkson as the doctor who quietly listens to Lars's story. Patricia Clarkson's fantastic performance gives her character as a wise and understanding doctor credibility and warmth. Actually the snowbound town and its people who support Lars are depicted sympathetically without being condescending or sentimental. This is a rare achievement, considering the tricky nature of the central topic.In a nutshell, "Lars and the Real Girl" is a touching, life-affirming film. Its approach may be far from conventional, but its theme itself is universal.

reviewText: What is amusing and what is sad can sometimes be highly subjective and hard to define.  This film finds both  the humor and the pathos in the life of Lars, a socially awkward loner who buys a Real Doll and treats it as if it were a real woman.  You have to wonder if it was societal pressure or his own neuroses that finally pushed him to purchase this doll.  People wonder why he is by himself a lot or else assume that he is gay.  With all of that pressure and speculation, perhaps his actions are not so hard to understand after all.Ryan Gosling gives a nuanced performance as Lars, who cannot bear to be hugged or touched too much because he finds it physically painful, but who connects quite well with his lifesize plastic partner.  Patricia Clarkson is lovely as his compassionate doctor, who seems to be the only one who understands why Lars needs to go through this process in order to come to terms with his identity.It's refreshing that the doll is never used for sexual pleasure, which is the real reason why many people purchase it in the first place.In the end, the doll is no longer necessary, but we are left with some unanswered questions:  Will Lars ever get over his fear of being hugged?  Will he be able to embrace his brother's child without dropping it?There is also one quite unbelievable scene involving paramedics rushing the doll into the hospital via ambulance.  There is no way that anyone could abuse the 911 system in real life and get away with it.Quibbles aside, this movie is inoffensive and can be shown to people between 18 and 80 or so.

reviewText: "Lars and the Real Girl" is one of the more original movies I've seen in quite some time.  It is easy to see how this incredibly inqenious screenplay could have devolved into a farcical, over-the-top picture.  A film about a mentally ill, early 30s Midwestern guy who buys a sex doll to keep him company easily could have been a train wreck.  Fortunately, it is a gem of film showcasing the talents of Ryan Gosling along with a stellar supporting performances, most notably Patricia Clarkson as Lars doctor.Lars (Gosling) sister-in-law's pregnancy resurfaces painful childhood memories and brings Lars' mental illness to the forefront.  Lars is unable to connect physically and emotionally with another person.  The only thing able to bring Lars out of his "shell" and connect is Bianca.  The only catch:  Bianca is a sex doll Lars created and bought on the internet.  The initial shock and amusement of the tight knit community turns to acceptance as they begin to go along with the whole thing.  Part of the reason is because everyone adores Lars and his sweet innocence and decency.  If it all sounds crazy and absurd, it is, but the movie never succumbs to the temptation to either get too sentimental or slapstick.  There are scenes that will cause you to burst into laughter, but instantly bring you back to tender consideration for Lars and his situation."Lars and Real Girl" works because it is about people caring and connecting with each other, taking the time to understand who they are and why they are that way, and a community rallying together to help someone they love, in spite of their problems.  This is a tender, funny and sentimental (in a really good way) movie that will surprise you, make you think and most of all, warm your heart.
